{{Overquotation|date=August 2015}}
'''''Applied Drama''''', also known as '''''Applied Theatre, Interactive Theatre<ref>{{cite journal|last=Sant|first=Toni|title=The Applied and Interactive Theatre Guide|date=22 Sep 2006|url=http://www.interactiveimprov.com/aitg.html}}</ref> '''or '''Applied Drama''' '''and Theatre (ADT)''''' is an [[umbrella term]] for the use of [[drama]] practice in an educational, community or therapeutic context.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Taylor|first=Phillip|title=Applied Theatre/Drama: an e-debate in 2004|journal=Research in Drama Education: The Journal of Applied Theatre and Performance J|date=February 2006|volume=11|issue=1|pages=90–95|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/13569780500437960#.UZmDvSsa-nk|doi=10.1080/13569780500437960}}</ref> It is often done in non-theatrical spaces, with participants who do not consider themselves to be artists.
There are several forms and practices considered to be under the umbrella of Applied Drama. In all these fields approaches and methods of [[Applied improvisation|Applied Improvisation]] are used.
==History and definition== Applied Drama is a term that has been contested{{By whom|date=August 2015}}, gaining popularity towards the end of the 20th century to describe drama practice in an educational, community or therapeutic context.
James Thompson states that "Applied theatre is a participatory theatre created by people who would not usually make theatre. It is, I would hope, a practice by, with and for the excluded and marginalised." <ref>{{Cite book|title = Applied Theatre: Bewilderment and Beyond|last = Thompson|first = James|publisher = Peter Lang|year = 2008|isbn = |location = Oxford|pages = 15}}</ref>
Judith Ackyroyd confirms the inclusion of both of these elements in ADT: "I have identified two features which I believe to be central to our understanding of applied theatre; an intention to generate change (of awareness, attitude, behaviour, etc), and the participation of the audience."<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Applied Theatre: Problems and Possibilities|last = Ackroyd|first = Judith|date = 2000|journal = Applied Theatre Researcher|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref>
Applied drama can be either scripted or unscripted.<ref name=":0">{{cite book|quote = |title = Applied Theatre, International Case Studies and Challenges for Practice|year = 2009|publisher = Intellect Publishers|location = Briston, UK|page = 7|editor1=Monica Prendergast |editor2=Juliana Saxton }}</ref> Some practitioners focus primarily on improvisation, whereas others introduce a range of artistic practices, such as developing scripted plays,<ref>http://www.cleanbreak.org.uk retrieved 30 November 2011</ref> devised performances,<ref>http://www.oilycart.org.uk.retrieved{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} 30 November 2011</ref> or indigenous forms of cultural performance, sometimes combined with new forms of digital communication.<ref>See, for example www.charles-royal.com, www.africanperformers.com, www.storyworkshop.org. retrieved 30 November 2011</ref>
==Fields associated with applied drama==
===Playback Theatre=== {{Main|Playback Theatre}} [[Playback Theatre]] involves audience or group members telling stories from their lives and viewing them as enacted by actors improvising. It can also be used in conjunction with [[Narrative Therapy]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=Playback theatre and narrative therapy: introducing a new model|journal=Dramatherapy |volume=35 |issue=2 |pages=108–119 |quote=Article elaborates how such integration (Playback theatre with Narrative Therapy) can be achieved and how it can contribute to the process of narrative re-authoring.|doi=10.1080/02630672.2013.821865|year=2013|last1=Barak|first1=Adi}}</ref>
===Drama in Health Education=== Drama in healthcare is drama created in medical contexts, often with the intention of rehabilitation.<ref>{{cite book|last=Warren|first=Bernie|title=Using the Creative Arts in Therapy and Healthcare: A Practical Introduction|publisher=Routledge|pages=115}}</ref>
This form of Applied Drama focuses on using theatre to educate, engage, and stimulate healing in medical professionals, patients, and the general public. Theatre and drama in healthcare are tilted towards conscientizing the populace about their health and improving their health and longevity irrespective of status or social stratification. This form of drama is often used to educate people on important health issues such as healthy eating, grief and loss, exercise, and sexual assault prevention. Examples include using actors to [[Role-playing|role-play]] health ailments in order to train healthcare professionals, performing plays focused on [[Preventive healthcare|primary prevention]], and facilitating drama workshops for patients.
===Drama Therapy=== {{Main|Drama therapy}} [[Drama therapy]] is the use of Applied Drama techniques to facilitate personal growth and promote mental health.<ref>Loretta Gallo-Lopez, Lawrence C. C. Rubin -Play-Based Interventions for Children and Adolescents on the ... 2012- Page 100 "An overview of drama therapy is provided next, along with support for the use of drama therapy with children with ASd."</ref>
Drama therapy is rooted in a clinical practice, facilitated by licensed clinicians, that stimulates language, cognitive development and builds resilience.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Clinical Applications of Drama Therapy in Child and Adolescent Treatment|last = Weber|first = Anna Marie|publisher = Brunner-Routledge|year = 2005|isbn = |location = New York|pages = |last2 = Haen|first2 = Craig}}</ref>
===Theatre for Development=== {{Main|Theatre for Development}} Theatre for Development uses Applied Drama techniques to facilitate development in [[less developed countries]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Kabaso|first=Sydney|title=Theater for Development in Zambia|year=2013|publisher=Kabsy Digital Media|location=Zambia|page=20}}</ref>
===Drama in Education === {{Confusing section|date=August 2015}} Drama in Education can allow students to develop an understanding of themselves and others.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Arts, The Ontario Curriculum, Grades 1-8|url=http://www.edu.gov.on.ca/eng/curriculum/elementary/arts18curr.pdf|publisher=Ontario Ministry of Education and Training|accessdate=20 May 2013|page=5|quote=Education in the arts is essential to students’ intellectual, social, physical, and emotional growth.}}</ref> Kathleen Galllagher has argued that 'What is clear is that there is no correct pedagogical model on offer for drama education. [...] In theatre pedagogy, we not only endow experience with meaning, but we are - as players - invited to make manifest our own subjectivities in the world evoked through character and play, a world laden with metaphor and nuance, a world where relationship to other and self-spectatorship are in dynamic and unrelenting interaction.'<ref>See 'Emergent Conceptions in Theatre Pedagogy and Production' in ''How Theatre Education: Convergences and Counterpoints'' 3-13, pp. 12-13.</ref>
===Theatre in Education=== {{Main|Theatre in education}} {{Overly detailed|date=August 2015|section=yes}} Theatre in education (TIE) originated in Britain in the mid-1960s. Monica Prendergast and Juliana Saxton cite TIE as "one of the two historic roots of applied theatre practice."<ref name=":0" /> TIE typically includes a theatre company performing in an educational setting (i.e. a school) for youth, including interactive and performative moments.
Practitioner Lynn Hoare defines TIE as a combination of "theatrical elements with interactive moments in which audience participants (in or out of role) work with actor-teachers towards an educational or social goal, using the tools of theatre in service of this goal."<ref>Hoare, Lynn. Considering the Form: Fundamental Factors in Devising for Theatre-In-Education. Thesis. University of Texas at Austin. n.p. Print.</ref>
Scholar Helen Nicholson notes that this work "involves professional theatre-makers working with young people in all kinds of educational settings and learning environments, including schools, hospitals, theaters, museums and heritage sites."<ref name=":2">Nicholson, Helen, Applied Drama: The Gift of Theatre, Palgrave MacMillan, Basingstoke, UK, 2005</ref>
TIE seeks to educate young people in issues that are relevant to both them and their communities, for example: bullying, dating violence, environmental preservation, and peer conflict resolution. "TIE companies have always been among the most socially conscious of theatre groups, consistently choosing to examine issues they believe to be of direct relevance to the lives of the children with whom they work."<ref>Jackson, Anthony, and Chris Vine. Learning through Theatre: The Changing Face of Theatre in Education. 3rd ed. New York: Routledge, 2013. Print.</ref>
"Theatre for Dialogue" (TFD) is a more recent term describing a model that was created specifically for the University of Texas at Austin campus community which pulls methods and theory from a variety of applied theatre practices such as TO and TIE. In her thesis, Spring Snyder explains that "Theatre For Dialogue performances explore the intersection between theatre and education as a way to investigate, reflect, provoke dialogue and serve as a rehearsal for reality without asking participants to share their own personal experiences. Although some of the Theatre For Dialogue’s roots originate from an adapted form of Boal’s Theatre of the Oppressed’s forum structure, it is Theatre in Education (TIE) that more closely aligns with TFD."<ref>Snyder, Spring. A Transformative Classroom Experience: Exploring Campus Mental Health through Theatre For Dialogue. Thesis. University of Texas at Austin. 2015. Print.</ref>
===Prison Theatre=== In prison theatre, practitioners engage offenders in correctional facilities, jails, prisons, and detention centers in exploring drama work often with the objective of education or rehabilitation.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shailor|first1=Jonathan|title=Performing New Lives: Prison Theatre|date=2010|publisher=Jessica Kingsley Publishers|quote=In the prison setting, as elsewhere, the needs that theatre addresses are those of self-expression and identity, freedom (of the imagination), creativity, and community.}}</ref>
Examples include Wabash Valley Correctional Facility’s ''Shakespeare in Shackles'' where maximum security prisoners learn about and perform [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]]. The University of Texas’ Center for Women and Gender Studies’ Performing Justice Project works with incarcerated female youth to learn about gender and racial justice while devising a play based on the youth’s unique experiences.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Drama Workshops for Anger Management and Offending Behaviour|last = Thompson|first = James|publisher = Jessica Kingsley Publishers|year = 1999|isbn = |location = |pages = }}</ref>
=== Theatre of the Oppressed === {{Main|Theatre of the Oppressed}}The '''Theatre of the Oppressed''' (TO) describes theatrical forms that the Brazilian theatre practitioner Augusto Boal first developed in the 1960s, initially in Brazil and later in Europe. Boal's techniques aim to use theatre as means of promoting social and political change through allowing the audience to take an active role in the creation of the show. Theatre of the Oppressed can include aspects of [[Forum Theatre]], [[Invisible theater|Invisible Theatre]], Legislative Theatre and [[Image theatre|Image Theatre]].
=== Museum Theatre === {{Main|Museum theatre}}Museum theatre aims to use theatrical techniques to add emotion and value to the museum experience.<ref name="IMTAL {{!}} IMTAL">{{Cite web|title = IMTAL {{!}} IMTAL|url = http://imtal-europe.net/|website = imtal-europe.net|accessdate = 2015-06-14}}</ref> It is typically more common in cultural institutions like heritage sites, history museums, and science and industry museums.<ref>Catherine Hughes. Museum theatre: Communicating with visitors through drama. Heinemann Drama, 1998.</ref><ref>Genshaft, Lindsay Michelle. "Bridging theatre and visual art: the role of an applied theatre practitioner in a fine art museum." (2011).</ref> As with the other forms of applied drama, it can involve a variety of theatrical techniques.<ref name="IMTAL {{!}} IMTAL" />
==See also== *[[Theatre pedagogy]] *[[Improvisation]] *[[William Shakespeare]]

==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130411061014/http://www.imprology.com/games/viewallgames.html The Far Games] Educational drama and improvisation games *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100821184457/http://www.bced.gov.bc.ca/irp/drama810/apg.htm Drama Games] Drama games *[http://www.creativedrama.com/ Creative Drama] Educational Resource *[http://code.on.ca/ The Council of Ontario Drama and Dance Educators] Resources, lessons and articles on Drama in Education. *[http://www.dramatoolkit.co.uk/ Drama Toolkit] Drama games, strategies, schemes and resources. *[http://www.griffith.edu.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0011/381926/02-Article-2-Skeiker-FINAL.pdf]

{{multiple issues|{{unreferenced|date=September 2012}} {{original research|date=September 2012}}}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} The '''authority''' of a text is its reliability as a witness to the author's intentions. These intentions could be initial, medial or final, but intentionalist editors (most notably represented by [[Fredson Bowers]] and [[G. Thomas Tanselle]] editing school) generally attempt to retrieve final authorial intentions. The concept is of particular importance for textual critics, whether they believe that authorial intention is recoverable, or whether they think that this recovery is impossible.
Here are some examples of authority:
* The only authority for the works of the [[Ancient Rome|Roman]] poet [[Catullus]] derives from a lost manuscript, of which three copies reside in the [[Bibliothèque Nationale de France|National Library]] in Paris, the [[Bodleian Library]] at [[Oxford]], and the [[Vatican Library]] in Rome (the ''Codex Vaticanus''). No one knows, or can ever know, how close this manuscript comes to [[Catullus]]' intentions—in other words, how great its authority is. * It is generally thought that the Q1 ('[[Bad quarto]]') edition of [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]]'s ''[[Hamlet]]'' is an [[copyright infringement|unauthorized]] copy, reconstructed from memory by one of the actors. If this is so, then it has some authority, but much less than the first authorized quarto, Q2 (1602). In comparison, however, it might be a useful authority to the cuts and adaptations made in the performance it was based on. * The [[First Folio]] edition of ''[[Julius Caesar (play)|Julius Caesar]]'' (1623) is the only authoritative source, since it is the copy-text of all future editions. * A diary which is probably authentic has total authority.
A text's authority is made more problematic when it has more than one author, when it falsely asserts itself to be someone else's work, or when it is revised many times. For instance:
* The forged [[Hitler Diaries|diaries]] of [[Adolf Hitler]] have no authority as the work of their supposed author, but they do have authority as a witness to the intentions of [[Konrad Kujau]], the forger. * A page on Wikipedia could be said to indicate the intentions of the aggregate of users who have edited it up to that point: it has multiple authority. But many of its editors will disagree with one another about what the page should contain. The idea of 'final intention' does not easily apply, since the page is never complete, and since a recent change (e.g. a piece of vandalism) might not be satisfactory to any of the other editors except the one who made it. * The [[quarto]] edition of [[Shakespeare]]'s [[King Lear]] differs from the later [[folio (printing)|folio]] edition in many ways. Most modern versions collate the two, preferring one edition in one passage and the other in another. But some editors, such as [[Stanley Wells]], argue they are separate works with different artistic intentions, and that neither of them has more authority.
Authority can also be related to a particular edition, especially if this edition reaches a degree of popularity.
==See also==

{{good article}} [[File:Banner of Poland.jpg|thumb|upright|right|Banner of the Republic on display in the [[Royal Castle in Warsaw]]]] Throughout most of the [[history of Poland]], the '''banner of [[Poland]]''' was one of the main symbols of the Polish State, normally reserved for use by the [[head of state]]. Although its design changed with time, it was generally a [[Banner#Heraldic banners|heraldic banner]], i.e., one based directly on the [[Coat of arms of Poland|national coat of arms]]: a crowned White Eagle on a red field (''[[Gules]] an eagle [[Argent]] crowned [[Or (heraldry)|Or]]''). The banner should not be confused with the [[flag of Poland]], a white and red [[c:Bicolor_flags#Horizontal_bicolor|horizontal bicolor]], officially adopted in 1919.
Derived from early [[Slavic peoples|Slavic]] flag-like objects, a royal [[Banner#Heraldic banners|banner of arms]] dates as far back as the 11th century [[Common Era|CE]]. A symbol of royal authority, it was used at coronations and in battles. In the [[History of Poland (1918–1939)|interwar]] period, it was replaced with the '''Banner of the Republic of Poland''', which was part of the presidential insignia. A national banner is not mentioned in the current (2007) regulations on Polish national symbols, although today's [[Jack of the President of the Republic of Poland|presidential jack]] is based directly on the pre-war design for the Banner of the Republic.
==History== === From ''stanica'' to ''chorągiew'' === [[File:Maurycy.jpg|thumb|upright|right|100px|Polish replica of the [[Holy Lance]], [[Wawel Cathedral]] Treasury, [[Kraków]]]]
The banner of Poland traces its origins to the early [[Slavic peoples|Slavic]] [[vexilloid]]s known as ''stanice'' (pronounced {{IPA-pl|staˈɲit͡sɛ|}}; singular: ''stanica''), probably used at least as early as the 10th century [[Common Era|CE]]. Although no specimens or images are preserved, a ''stanica'' was probably a cloth draped vertically from a horizontal crosspiece attached to a wooden pole or [[spear]], resembling the [[Roman Empire|Roman]] ''[[vexillum]]''. It was both a religious and military symbol; the ''stanice'' were kept either inside or outside [[Slavic mythology|pagan]] temples in peacetime and were taken to war as military insignia.<ref name=znamier>{{cite book | last = Znamierowski | first = Alfred | title = Stworzony do chwały | publisher = Editions Spotkania | year = 1995 | location = Warsaw | pages = 299 | isbn = 83-7115-055-5|language=pl}}</ref>
[[File:Christianization od Poland fragment.jpg|thumb|150px|left|Polish ''vexillum'' in 966 as imagined by [[Jan Matejko]] in 1889]]
With Poland's conversion to [[Christianity]] in the late 10th century, the pagan ''stanice'' were probably Christianized by replacing pagan symbols with Christian ones such as images of patron saints, or a [[labarum|Chi-Rho]] or dove symbolizing the [[Holy Spirit]].<ref name=pietras>{{cite paper | author = Pietras, Tomasz | title = Od słowiańskich stanic do orzełka wojskowego. Z dziejów polskiej symboliki wojskowej. | version = | publisher = | date = | url = http://warsztathistoryka.uni.lodz.pl/heraldyka/wojskowe.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = 2007-10-20|language=pl}}</ref> In 1000 CE, during his pilgrimage to the tomb of [[Adalbert of Prague|Saint Adalbert]] in [[Gniezno]], the capital of Poland until about 1040, Emperor [[Otto III, Holy Roman Emperor|Otto III]] officially recognized Duke [[Boleslaus I of Poland|Boleslaus the Brave]] as King of Poland (see [[Congress of Gniezno]]), crowning him and presenting him with a replica of the [[Holy Lance]], also known as [[Saint Maurice]]'s Spear. This [[relic]], together with the ''vexillum'' attached to it, was probably the first insignia of the nascent [[Kingdom of Poland (1025–1385)|Kingdom of Poland]], a symbol of King Boleslaus's rule, and of his allegiance to the Emperor. It remains unknown what images, if any, were painted or embroidered on the ''vexillum''.<ref name=znamier/><ref name=lileyko/>
A royal banner was used as early as the reign of [[Boleslaus II of Poland|Boleslaus the Generous]] (r. 1076-1079). The earliest mention of a banner ({{lang-pl|chorągiew}}, pronounced {{IPA-pl|xɔˈrɔŋɡʲɛf|}}) bearing the sign of an [[eagle]] is found in [[Wincenty Kadłubek]]'s ''Chronicle'' which says that Duke [[Casimir II of Poland|Casimir the Just]] fought the [[Ruthenians]] in 1182 "under the sign of the victorious eagle". A seal of Duke [[Premislaus II of Poland|Premislaus II]] from 1290 shows the ruler holding a banner emblazoned with a crowned eagle. Five years later, Premislaus was crowned King of Poland, and he made the crowned White Eagle a [[Coat of arms of Poland|national coat of arms]]. During the reign of King [[Władysław I the Elbow-high|Ladislaus the Elbow-High]] (r. 1320–1333), the red cloth with the White Eagle was finally established as the Banner of the Kingdom of Poland (Polish: ''chorągiew Królestwa Polskiego''). The orientation of the eagle on the banner varied; its head could point either upwards or towards the [[Hoist (flag)|hoist]]. The actual rendering of the eagle changed with time according to new artistic styles.<ref name=znamier/>
The national banner was identical with that of [[Lesser Poland]], the territory where [[Kraków]], the capital of Poland until 1596, is located. It was therefore carried by the [[Standard-bearer]] of Kraków until that office was replaced by the Grand Standard-Bearer of the Crown of the Kingdom of Poland (Polish: ''[[chorąży]] wielki koronny'', [[Latin]]: ''vexillifer regni'').<ref name=znamier/>
=== Polish-Lithuanian union === [[File:Banner of Poland at Grunwald.jpg|thumb|right|Banner of Poland torn in the [[Battle of Grunwald]] (1410) as painted by [[Jan Matejko]] in 1878]]
One of the most famous standard-bearers of Kraków was [[Marcin of Wrocimowice]] (d. 1442) who carried the national banner in the [[Battle of Grunwald]] ([[Stębark|Tannenberg]]) in 1410. The military unit (''[[chorągiew]]'') that went to the battle under that banner comprised the elite of Polish knights, including such chivalrous celebrities as [[Zawisza the Black]], which is a clear sign that the banner, described by the chronicler [[Jan Długosz]] as "the great banner of Kraków Territory", was also the insignia of the entire kingdom. During the course of the battle, according to Długosz, the national banner slipped out of Marcin's hand and fell to the ground, but it was quickly picked up and saved from destruction by the Polish army's most valiant knights, which further motivated the Poles to strive for victory over the [[Teutonic Knights]].<ref name="długosz">{{cite book | last = Długosz | first = Jan | authorlink = Jan Długosz |author2=transl. J. Mruk |author3=edit. H. Samsonowicz | title = Polska Jana Długosza. Wybór z pism | publisher = | year = 1984 | location = Warsaw | pages = | url = http://www.staropolska.gimnazjum.com.pl/sredniowiecze/dziejopisarstwo/Dlugosz.html | isbn = |language=pl}}</ref>
[[File:Chorągiew królewska króla Zygmunta III Wazy.svg|thumb|left|Banner of Poland during the reign of [[Sigismund III Vasa]].]] With the establishment of a [[dynastic union]] with the [[Grand Duchy of Lithuania]] in 1386, it became customary to use two banners—Polish and Lithuanian—as equally important insignia of royal authority. In the mid-16th century, before the creation of the [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]] ([[real union]]) in 1569, a single banner for the entire entity also came into use. The Commonwealth banner was initially plain white emblazoned with the [[Coat of arms of the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth|arms of the Commonwealth]] which combined the heraldic charges of Poland (White Eagle) and Lithuania ([[Coat of arms of Lithuania|Pursuer]]). During the 17th century, the banner was often divided into three or four horizontal stripes of white and red, ending with swallowtails. [[Royal elections in Poland|Elective kings']] dynastic arms were often placed in an [[inescutcheon]]. Variants with the White Eagle and the Pursuer placed side by side without an [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|escutcheon]] directly in the field or with the Eagle on the [[obverse]] and the Pursuit on the reverse side of the banner were also used.<ref name=znamier/> [[File:Banner of Sigismund III Vasa.svg|thumb|Royal Standard of [[Sigismund III Vasa]].]] During royal coronations, however, separate banners for each of the two constituent nations of the Commonwealth were still used. Crown (i.e., Polish) and Lithuanian standard-bearers carried the furled banners in a procession to the royal cathedral where, shortly after the anointment and just before the crowning of the king-elect, they handed the banners to the [[Primate (bishop)|primate]] who unfurled them and handed them to the kneeling king. The king would then stand up and give the unfurled banners back to the standard-bearers.<ref name=lileyko>{{cite book | last = Lileyko | first = Jerzy | title = Regalia polskie | publisher = Krajowa Agencja Wydawnicza | year = 1987 | location = Warsaw | pages = 153 | isbn = 83-03-02021-8|language=pl}}</ref>
=== Time of partitions === [[Partitions of Poland]] at the end of the 18th century brought an end to the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth. In 1815, the [[Congress of Vienna]] established a semi-independent [[Congress Poland|Kingdom of Poland]] (known as Congress Kingdom) under control of and in personal union with the [[Russian Empire]]. The King ([[Tsar]]) of Poland at that time used a white royal banner emblazoned with the arms of the Congress Kingdom—a black double-headed [[Coat of arms of the Russian Federation|Russian eagle]] with the Polish White Eagle in an inescutcheon.<ref name=znamier/>
=== Interbellum === [[File:Pilsudski pogrzeb laweta.jpg|thumb|right|[[Józef Piłsudski]]'s coffin draped in the banner of the Republic (1935)]] In August 1919, the [[Sejm]] (lower house of parliament) of the renascent [[Second Republic of Poland|Republic of Poland]] adopted a law defining the Banner of the Republic of Poland (''chorągiew Rzeczypospolitej Polskiej''). The banner was part of the insignia of the head of state—the State Leader (''[[Naczelnik Państwa]]'') and, later, [[President of the Republic of Poland|President of the Republic]]. It was plain red emblazoned with the crowned White Eagle and bordered with a ''wężyk generalski'', a wavy line used in the Polish military as a symbol of [[generał|general's]] rank. It was modified on December 27, 1927 to reflect the adoption of a new official rendering of the national coat of arms.<ref name=znamier/>
As a symbol of presidential authority, the banner was carried or flown to mark the presence of the head of state and, at the same time, the commander-in-chief. It was flown on the president's official residence, and used as a car flag and instead of number plates on the president's vehicle. The banner was also used on special national occasions including the welcome ceremony for [[Ignacy Paderewski]] in [[Poznań]] in 1918 and [[Poland's Wedding to the Sea|Poland's wedding to the Baltic Sea]] in [[Puck, Poland|Puck]] in 1920. It also draped the coffins of [[Henryk Sienkiewicz]] in 1924, the [[Tomb of the Unknown Soldier, Warsaw|Unknown Soldier]] in 1925, and Marshal [[Józef Piłsudski]] in 1935.<ref name=znamier/>
=== Second World War and People's Poland === Following the [[Nazi Germany|German]]-[[Soviet Union|Soviet]] [[September Campaign|invasion of Poland]] in September 1939, President [[Ignacy Mościcki]] fled to [[Romania]], taking the presidential insignia, including two specimens of the Banner of the Republic, with him. The banners were kept by the [[Polish government-in-exile]] in [[London]] until after the [[fall of Communism in Poland]] in 1989.<ref name=znamier/>
Meanwhile, the new Communist authorities at home used a modified version of the banner with a crownless White Eagle and a wider border. It was first used during the celebrations of the anniversary of the battle of Grunwald in 1945. Officially abandoned in 1955, the banner continued to be used in practice by the [[Prime Minister of the Republic of Poland|prime minister]] and, during the 1960s, by the [[Polish Council of State|Council of State]], a collective head of state of the time.<ref name=znamier/>
=== Third Republic === [[File:Flag of the President of Poland.svg|thumb|150px|right|[[Jack of the President of the Republic of Poland|Presidential jack]] based on the former Banner of the Republic of Poland]]
{{Main|Jack of the President of the Republic of Poland}}
On December 22, 1990, the last Polish president-in-exile, [[Ryszard Kaczorowski]], handed the presidential insignia, including one of the banners rescued by Mościcki in 1939, to [[Lech Wałęsa]], the first democratically elected president of post-war Poland. The ceremony, held at the [[Royal Castle in Warsaw]] was seen as a symbol of the [[History of Poland (1989–present)|Third Republic's]] continuity with the pre-war Second Republic. However, since legal regulations on national symbols did not recognize a national banner at that time, the banner brought by Kaczorowski did not become the presidential insignia again but was instead donated to the Royal Castle museum where it is now on display. The other of the two banners remains in the [[Polish Institute and Sikorski Museum|Sikorski Institute]] in London.<ref name=znamier/> Today, a [[kilim]] embroidered with the design of the pre-war Banner of the Republic is hanging in the [[Senate of the Republic of Poland|Senate]] chamber, above the chair reserved for the President of Poland.<ref>{{cite web |last=Mycielska |first=Dorota |authorlink= |title=Sala obrad Senatu |work=Senat Rzeczypospolitej Polskiej |publisher=Kancelaria Senatu RP |date=January 2006 |origyear=September 1997 |url=http://www.senat.gov.pl/senatrp/noty/sala.pdf |format=PDF |doi= |accessdate=2007-10-28 |language=pl |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100216041109/http://www.senat.gov.pl/senatrp/noty/sala.pdf |archivedate=2010-02-16 |df= }}</ref>
In 1996, the Minister of National Defense established a [[jack of the President of the Republic of Poland]] with the purpose of flying it on [[Polish Navy]] ships while the commander-in-chief is on board. The jack is identical in its design to the former Banner of the Republic of Poland.<ref>{{pl icon}} ''Zarządzenie Ministra Obrony Narodowej z dnia 29 stycznia 1996 r. w sprawie szczegółowych zasad używania znaków Sił Zbrojnych Rzeczypospolitej Polskiej oraz ustalenia innych znaków używanych w Siłach Zbrojnych Rzeczypospolitej Polskiej'' ([http://www.abc.com.pl/serwis/mp/1996/0178.htm M.P.96.14.178] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930015219/http://www.abc.com.pl/serwis/mp/1996/0178.htm |date=2007-09-30 }})</ref> In 2005, the use of the presidential jack was extended to all branches of the [[Polish Armed Forces]].<ref>{{pl icon}} ''Zarządzenie Ministra Obrony Narodowej z dnia 14 grudnia 2005 r. zmieniające zarządzenie w sprawie szczegółowych zasad używania znaków Sił Zbrojnych Rzeczypospolitej Polskiej oraz ustalenia innych znaków używanych w Siłach Zbrojnych Rzeczypospolitej Polskiej'' ([http://www.abc.com.pl/serwis/mp/2005/1165.htm M.P.05.82.1165] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930033325/http://www.abc.com.pl/serwis/mp/2005/1165.htm |date=2007-09-30 }})</ref> It was first flown on land during a [[Constitution of May 3, 1791|Constitution Day]] ceremony at the [[Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Warsaw]] on May 3, 2005.
==Gallery== <gallery> File:Pontyfikał Ciołka.JPG|Crown and Lithuanian Standard-Bearers holding banners of Poland and Lithuania respectively in [[Erazm Ciołek (bishop of Płock)|Erazm Ciołek]]'s ''[[Ciołek's Missal|Pontifical]]'' (ca. 1515) File:Great Chorąży of the Polish Crown.jpg|Grand Standard-Bearer of the Crown, [[Sebastian Sobieski]], as painted anonymously on the [[Stockholm Roll]] (ca. 1605) File:Presidential jack unknown soldier.jpg|A [[Jack of the President of the Republic of Poland|presidential jack]] flying at the [[Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Warsaw]] during a [[Constitution of May 3, 1791|Constitution Day]] ceremony </gallery>

{{short description|Italian company}} {{about||the [[Romania]]n village|Sălățig|the instrument|Bulgari (instrument)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2011}} {{Infobox company | name = Bulgari S.p.A. | logo = Bulgari_logo.svg | image = Roma, Piazza Nicosia, 20.jpg | image_caption = Headquarters in Rome | type = [[Privately held company|Privately held]] [[società per azioni]] | founder = Sotirios Voulgaris | foundation = {{start date and age|1884}} | location = Rome, Italy | key_people = {{ubl|[[Paolo Bulgari]] (Chairman)|Jean-Christophe Babin
(CEO)}} | industry = Retail | products = {{flatlist| *[[Jewellery]] *watches *[[fashion accessory|accessories]] *[[Perfume|fragrance]]s *cosmetics}} | homepage = [http://www.bulgari.com/ www.bulgari.com] | revenue = €1.069 billion (2010){{cite web |url=http://ir.bulgari.com/~/media/Files/B/Bulgari-IR-2010/pdf/annual-report-2010v2.pdf? |title=Annual Report 2010 |accessdate=19 May 2011 |publisher=Bulgari}} | operating_income = €85.3 million (2010) | net_income = €38.0 million (2010) | assets = €1.490 billion (end 2010) | equity = €934.0 million (end 2010) | num_employees = 3,815 (end 2010) | owner = [[LVMH]] (50,4%) }} '''Bulgari''' S.p.A ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|b|ʊ|l|g|ər|i}}, {{IPA-it|ˈbulɡari|lang}}; [[stylized]] as '''BVLGARI''') is an Italian luxury brand known for its [[jewelry]], [[Watch|watches]], [[Aroma compound|fragrances]], [[Fashion accessory|accessories]] and [[Leather|leather goods]]. While the majority of design, production and marketing is overseen and executed by Bvlgari, the company does, at times, partner with other entities. For example, Bvlgari eyewear is produced through a [[License|licensing agreement]] with [[Luxottica]], and, in 2001, the brand formed a [[joint venture]] with Group [[Marriott International]] to launch its hotel brand, Bvlgari Hotels & Resorts, a collection of properties and resort destinations around the world. Currently part of the [[LVMH|LVMH Group]], Bvlgari was founded in Rome in 1884 by the [[silversmith]] Sotirios Voulgaris (Italian: Sotirio Bulgari) as a single jewellery shop that has, over the years, become an international brand. The company has evolved into a player in the luxury market, with an established and growing network of stores.{{Cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/2001/02/13/europe/bulgari/|title=Head of Italian luxury goods firm says new hotel venture will boost profits|last=|first=|date=February 13, 2011|website=CNN|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} ==Etymology== The [[trademark]] is usually written BVLGARI in the classical [[Latin alphabet]], and is derived from the [[surname]] of the company's founder Sotirios Voulgaris (1857-1932, {{lang-el|Σωτήριος Βούλγαρης}}, {{IPA-el|soˈtirʝos ˈvulɣaris|pron}}){{cite web|title=Bulgari|url=http://www.fashionmodeldirectory.com/brands/bulgari/}}. The root of the surname [[Voulgaris]] is [[:wikt:Βούλγαρος|Βούλγαρ]] (''Voulgar''), which in [[Greek language|Greek]] translates as "Bulgarian".{{cite web|title=Bulgari|url=http://www.fashionmodeldirectory.com/brands/bulgari/}} In Italy he changed it to Bulgari, which although different, further emphasizes the same meaning and translates as "Bulgarians" or people of Bulgarian descent in [[Italian language|Italian]].{{cite web|title=Bulgari|url=http://www.fashionmodeldirectory.com/brands/bulgari/}} ==The Bvlgari logo== The BVLGARI logo was used for the first time in 1934, when its gilded brass letters graced the central doorway of the [[Via Condotti]] flagship.{{Cite web|url=http://www.museodelmarchioitaliano.com/route1/bulgari.php|title=The Bulgari logo|last=|first=|date=|website=Museo Del Marchio Italiano|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} In reference to [[ancient Rome]], the “U” was replaced with the letter “V”, and a logo was born. Since then, the [[trademark]] is written BVLGARI in the classical [[Latin alphabet]].{{cite web|title=Bulgari|url=http://www.fashionmodeldirectory.com/brands/bulgari/}}{{Cite book|title=BVLGARI|last=Amanda Triossi and Daniela Mascetti|first=|publisher=Electa|year=2009|isbn=9788837064921|location=Milan|pages=17}} ==History== === From its origins through the 1940s === The Voulgaris were a silversmithing family from the [[Epirus]] region of [[Ottoman Greece]]. Whether or not the [[Voulgaris]] family of [[Corfu]] and the Voulgaris family of the Italian jewelers Bulgari from [[Epirus]] share the same paternal line is unclear, but the count Stefanos Voulgaris denied that the Bulgari family of the Italian jewelers family is genealogically related to the Voulgaris family of [[Corfu]]. According to chronicles of the [[Voulgaris]] family written in [[Venice|Venetian]] [[Corfu]], the "Voulgaris family of [[Saint Spyridon]] of [[Corfu]]" descend from the royal figures of [[barbarian]] peoples from the [[Volga]] river, who "finally settled in [[Moesia]] near the [[Balkan mountains|Haemus mountains]]", so the founding father of this family was described as the "[[Triballi]]an" (de facto [[Serbia]]n) Prince [[Stefan Lazarevic]] in the 16th century testemant of the family, becoming such by taking refugee in the [[Republic of Venice|Venetian]] island [[Corfu]].{{cite book |last1=Stefanos Konstantinos |first1=Voulgaris |title=Ek Voulgareōn : hena oikogeneiako chroniko : plērophories gia tē mesaiōnikē Valkanikē |publisher=Vivliopōleion tēs "Hestias", I.D. Kollarou & Sias |isbn=9789600513219 |edition=1. ekd}|url=https://www.public.gr/product/books/greek-books/anthropology-social-sciences/biographies/ek-boylgareon/prod1722813pp/}}{{cite book |last1=Danova |first1=Penka |title=Le fonti della cronaca Bulgari |date=2015 |pages=5–34 |url=https://www.ceeol.com/search/article-detail?id=305359 }}{{cite web |title=“Булгари” да се наричам първа радост е за мене - trud.bg |url=http://archive.li/0qlUx}} The founder of the Bulgari brand is Sotirios Bulgari ({{lang-el|Σωτήριος Βούλγαρης}}, {{IPA-el|soˈtirʝos ˈvulɣaris|pron}}) who was born in March 1857 in the [[Aromanians|Aromanian]] village [[Kalarites]], [[Ottoman Empire]] and was one of eleven children of his father Georgios Voulgaris(1823-1889) and his [[Aromanians|Aromanian]] mother Eleni Stronggaris. In 1881, Sotirios Bulgari moved to Rome and, in 1884, opened his first store on via Sistina 85. In 1888, he married [[Aromanians|Aromanian]] Eleni Basio with whom he had six children: Constantine-Georgios(1889-1973), Leonidas-Georgios(1890-1966), Maria-Athena(1891-1976), Sofia(1893-1908), Alexandra(1895-1984) and Spyridon(1897-1932), so Leonidas-Georgios is the father of the current chairman of the company [[Paolo Bulgari]].{{cite web |title=Βούλγαρης Γ. Σωτήριος «Ο κοσμηματοπώλης των βασιλέων» |url=https://www.reporter.gr/Apopseis/Istories/235596-Boylgarhs-G-Swthrios-«O-kosmhmatopwlhs-twn-basilewn»?m=1 |language=el-gr}} In 1905, he unveiled the [[Via Condotti]] shop that would become the company’s flagship.{{Cite book|title=BVLGARI|last=Amanda Triossi and Daniela Mascetti|first=|publisher=Electa|year=2009|isbn=9788837064921|location=Milan|pages=9-17}} In its early years, Bvlgari was known for [[silver]] pieces that borrowed elements from [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine]] and [[Islamic art]], combining them with floral motifs. At the time, Paris was the apex of fashion and creativity, and its trends influenced Sotirio’s designs for decades: jewels of the early 20s were characterised by [[platinum]] [[Art Deco]] settings while those of the 30s featured geometric diamond motifs—sometimes set in combination with coloured [[Gemstone|gemstones]]. Convertible jewels were also popular during the time, and one of Bvlgari’s major piece was the ''Trombino'', a small trumpet-shaped ring. In 1932, Sotirio passed away, leaving the business to his two sons, [[Giorgio Bulgari|Giorgio]] (1890–1966) and Costantino (1889–1973), who each had a keen interest in precious stones and jewels. During the [[World War II|Second World War]], most new jewellery was crafted out of gold, as gems were scarce, and designs became more natural feeling. As the 40s came to a close, Bvlgari introduced ''Serpenti'' bracelet-watches.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bulgari.com/en-us/from_the_origins|title=From the origins|last=|first=|date=|website=Bvlgari Official website|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} === The 50s and the 60s: Colour revolution and Dolce Vita === In the 50s, some of Bvlgari best-known clients included [[Elizabeth Taylor]], [[Anna Magnani]], [[Ingrid Bergman]] and [[Gina Lollobrigida]]{{Cite book|title=Roma passion jewels|last=Meylan|first=Vincent|publisher=Electa|year=2015|isbn=9788891804549|location=Milan|pages=}} as Rome earned a reputation as "[[Hollywood on the Tiber]]" with the [[Cinecittà|Cinecittà studios]]. At the same time, Bvlgari went to a new style. The [[Post–World War II economic expansion|post-war boom]] saw a return to precious materials, particularly white metals covered in diamonds. In the 50s, Bvlgari launched its first floral brooches—called ''en tremblant'' because of their trembling diamond corollas. At the end of the 50s, Bvlgari began to establish its motifs, introducing structured, symmetrical shapes in yellow gold set with brilliant gems—chosen for their colour rather than intrinsic value. Among these multi-hued jewels, [[cabochon]] cuts were another innovation. These new pieces were a significant departure from classical Parisian design.[[File:Intersection of Aziz Aliyev Street & Neftchilar Avenue, Baku.jpg|thumb|A Bulgari shop in [[Baku]], [[Azerbaijan]]]] After Giorgio's death in 1966, his son [[Gianni Bulgari|Gianni]] led the company as co-chief executive with his cousin Marina.{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/people/bulgari-the-man-the-enigma/2007/01/07/1168104862949.html?page=fullpage#contentSwap1|title=Bulgari: the man, the enigma|date=8 January 2007|newspaper=The Age}} === The 70s: Eclectic creativity and global expansion === During the 1970s, Bvlgari stores opened in [[New York City|New York]], [[Geneva]], [[Monte Carlo]] and [[Paris]]. This era marks the beginning of the Group’s international expansion, with [[Gianni Bulgari|Gianni]] as chairman and CEO. A number of new motifs made their debut as well—jewels became recognisable for their angular forms, strong colours, oval elements with [[Cabochon|cabochons]], chains and maxi sautoirs, whilst the predominant use of yellow gold made precious pieces feel all the more wearable, and became known as a Bvlgari trademark.{{cn|date=August 2018}} In 1977, Bvlgari entered the world of horlogerie with the launch of the ''BVLGARI BVLGARI'' watch.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bulgari.com/en-us/70_eclectic_creativity|title=70 eclectic creativity|last=|first=|date=|website=Bvlgari Official website|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}''' '''At the time, Gianni led a complete overhaul of the company, focusing on product design.{{cite web|url=http://www.enigma.info/enigma/gianni-bulgari|title=Gianni Bulgari|publisher=Enigma|accessdate=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130111223841/http://www.enigma.info/enigma/gianni-bulgari/#|archive-date=11 January 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} === The 80s: Prêt-à-porter jewellery === In the early 80s, to oversee all production of Bvlgari watches, Bvlgari Time was founded in [[Switzerland]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.swisstime.ch/en-BVLGARI-m382.html|title=THE HISTORY OF BVLGARI|last=|first=|date=|website=Swisstime|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} In 1984, [[Paolo Bulgari|Paolo]] and [[Nicola Bulgari]], Giorgio’s sons, became Chairman and Vice-Chairman, respectively{{cite book|url=|title=International Directory of Company Histories|year=2010|volume=106|chapter=Bulgari S.p.A.|accessdate=}}, while their nephew, [[Francesco Trapani]], became Chief Executive Officer.{{Cite book|title=BVLGARI|last=Amanda Triossi and Daniela Mascetti|first=|publisher=Electa|year=2009|isbn=9788837064921|location=Milan|pages=}} In 1985, Gianni resigned as [[CEO]] and in 1987, he left the family business after selling his one-third stake in the company to his brothers Nicola and Paolo. === From the 90s to the new millennium === Bvlgari diversified its brand in 1993 with the launch of its first [[Aroma compound|fragrance]], ''Eau Parfumée au'' ''The Vert'' and the founding of Bvlgari Parfums in [[Switzerland]] to oversee the creation and production of all perfumes. In 1995, Bvlgari pushed ahead with an aggressive programme for growth, becoming listed on the [[Borsa Italiana|Milan Stock Exchange]] for the first time. In 1996, the brand launched its first accessories collection, beginning with [[silk]] scarves before developing a range of [[leather]] accessories and [[eyewear]]. In 1999, the brand launched the B.zero1 ring.{{what|date=August 2018}}{{Cite book|title=BVLGARI|last=Amanda Triossi and Daniela Mascetti|first=|publisher=Electa|year=2009|isbn=9788837064921|location=Milan|pages=}} The company has seen 150% revenue growth between 1997 and 2003. === The 21st century === The year 2000 was the beginning of an increasingly aggressive period of [[verticalization]] for Bvlgari, with the acquisition of the luxury [[Watchmaker|watchmaking]] brands Daniel Roth and [[Gérald Genta]]{{Cite web|url=http://www.fhs.swiss/eng/2000-07-05_44.html|title=Bulgari To Acquire Gerald Genta And Daniel Roth|last=|first=|date=July 5, 2000|website=Federation of the Swiss watch industry|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}, followed by the takeover of the jewellery firm Crova and of other companies that specialised in leather goods and watchmaking.{{Cite web|url=https://www.diamonds.net/News/NewsItem.aspx?ArticleID=11068&ArticleTitle=Bulgari+Acquires+100%25+Of+Crova|title=Bulgari Acquires 100% Of Crova|last=|first=|date=January 3, 2005|website=Diamonds|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} The opening of the first Bvlgari Hotel in [[Milan]] in 2004 further confirmed the expansion strategy of the brand, and was the result of a joint venture with Luxury Group, a division of [[Marriott International|Marriot International]]. In 2009, Bvlgari celebrated its 125th anniversary with a retrospective of the brand’s history, held in Rome at [[Palazzo delle Esposizioni]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.palazzoesposizioni.it/mostra/bulgari-tra-eternita-e-storia-125-anni-di-gioielli-italiani|title=BULGARI. TRA ETERNITÀ E STORIA. 125 ANNI DI GIOIELLI ITALIANI|last=|first=|date=May 22, 2009|website=Palazzo delle Esposizioni|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} That same year, the snake—a motif that appeared in Bvlgari collections from the 1960s—re-emerged as the emblem of the ''Serpenti'' collection. In 2011, Bvlgari signed a strategic alliance with [[LVMH|LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton SA]], the world’s leading luxury group. The agreement was based on a stock transfer of the Bulgari family's shares in Bvlgari S.p.A. to LVMH, an all-share deal for €4.3 billion ($6.01 billion), higher than LVMH had offered for any other company.Andrew Roberts and Tara Lachapelle (7 March 2011), [http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-03-07/bulgari-takeover-82-costlier-than-hermes-for-lvmh-real-m-a.html Bulgari Takeover 82% Costlier Than Hermes for LVMH: Real M&A] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110310165200/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-03-07/bulgari-takeover-82-costlier-than-hermes-for-lvmh-real-m-a.html|date=10 March 2011}} ''Business Week''. Under the deal, the Bulgari family sold their 50.4 per cent controlling stake in exchange for 3 per cent of [[LVMH]], thereby becoming the second-biggest family shareholder behind the [[Bernard Arnault|Arnaults in LVMH]].Paul Betts (7 March 2011), [http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/9f3fdab0-48e8-11e0-af8c-00144feab49a.html#ixzz1FzqOyxCi Bulgari is new jewel in LVMH crown] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150101081603/http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/9f3fdab0-48e8-11e0-af8c-00144feab49a.html#ixzz1FzqOyxCi|date=1 January 2015}} ''Financial Times''. The takeover doubled the size of LVMH’s watches and jewellery unit, which at the time of the acquisition included [[Tag Heuer]] timepieces and [[De Beers]] diamond necklaces. The acquisition concluded on 4 October 2011 as Bulgari was delisted from the [[Borsa Italiana]].{{citation needed|date=November 2016}} In 2014, Bvlgari celebrated the 130th anniversary of the brand. To mark the occasion, the shop at [[Via Condotti]] 10 was "reimagined" by the architect [[Peter Marino]], and reopened. On the same day, the brand donated € 1.5 million to the city of [[Rome]] for the restoration of the [[Spanish Steps]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/mar/20/bulgari-spanish-steps-donation-gift-people-rome-jeweller|title=Bulgari's Spanish Steps donation a €1.5m 'gift' to the people of Rome|last=|first=|date=March 20, 2014|website=The Guardian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} A few months after the Grand Opening, the [[Domvs Romana|DOMVS]] was inaugurated in the redesigned Bvlgari boutique, creating a gallery space to house of Bvlgari’s Heritage Collection.{{Cite web|url=https://www.corriere.it/moda/news/14_ottobre_24/bulgari-inaugura-domus-collezioni-storiche-gioielli-star-f6e995a8-5ba4-11e4-b4f3-89f9b4fdb64e.shtml|title=Bulgari inaugura una Domus per collezioni storiche e gioielli delle star|last=|first=|date=October 24, 2014|website=Corriere della Sera|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} In 2017, Bvlgari opened a new jewellery manufacturing headquarters in [[Valenza]]. The largest in Europe, with a total area of 14,000sqm, the Manufacture has been given a Gold [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design|LEED]] (Leadership in Energy & Environmental Design) certification for sustainability in its design.{{Cite web|url=https://www.usgbc.org/projects/manifattura-bulgari|title=LEED GOLD|last=|first=|date=2017|website=U.S. Green Building Council|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} The facility was built over the former home of the first goldsmith in Valenza, [[Francesco Caramora]]. The buildings follow the model of a Roman [[domus]], and are built around a central courtyard.Kathleen Beckett, "Bulgari Creates a New Jewelry-Making Center", ''New York Times'' [https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/30/fashion/jewelry-bulgari.html March 30, 2017] == Products == === Jewellery === Bvlgari’s jewellery collections include ''B.zero1, Divas’ Dream, Serpenti, BVLGARI BVLGARI, Parentesi,'' and a bridal line. {{citation needed|date=November 2016}} === Watches === Bvlgari’s watches collections include ''Octo, BVLGARI BVLGARI, Diagono'' and ''Haute Horlogerie'' creations for men, and ''LVCEA, Serpenti, Divas’ Dream, BVLGARI BVLGARI, B.zero1'' and High Jewellery timepieces for women. It mixes Italian design and Swiss watchmaking. The company's Swiss subsidiary, Bvlgari Haute Horlogerie SA, is responsible for Bvlgari watch production. It was founded in 1980 and is headquartered in [[Neuchâtel]]. Bvlgari Haute Horlogerie SA employs about 500 people.{{citation needed|date=November 2016}} === Fragrances === Bvlgari’s fragrance assortment includes ''Goldea, Splendida'' and ''Omnia'' for women, ''Bvlgari Man, Aqua'', ''the Classics'', and ''Blv Pour Homme'' for men, whilst ''Bvlgari Le Gemme'' and ''Eau Parfumée''. === Accessories & Leather goods === The creation of Bvlgari accessories and leather goods is handled in the Bvlgari atelier in [[Florence]]. Twice a year, Bvlgari presents its latest collections at [[Milan Fashion Week]], debuting them at the Spring/Summer and Fall/Winter shows. == Bvlgari Hotels & Resorts == [[File:BVLGARI in ifc mall Hong Kong 2016.jpg|thumb|BVLGARI in [[IFC Mall (Hong Kong)|ifc mall]], Hong Kong ]] In 2001, Bvlgari S.p.A. formed a joint venture with "Luxury Group", the Luxury Division of [[Marriott International]], to launch Bvlgari Hotels & Resorts, a collection of hotels and resort destinations around the world.{{citation needed|date=November 2016}} Their distinctive settings and Italian design by the architectural firm [[Antonio Citterio|Antonio Citterio-]]Patricia Viel characterise the properties of Bvlgari Hotel Group. Having grown from a curated collection of three—[[Milan]] (opened in 2004), [[Bali]] (2006) and [[London]] (2012)—the Bvlgari Hotels & Resorts portfolio has recently added [[Beijing]] (2017), [[Dubai]] (2017) and [[Shanghai]] (2018) properties. There are three additional Hotels in the works, with [[Moscow]], [[Paris]] and [[Tokyo]] slated to open between 2020 and 2022.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bulgarihotels.com/en_US/|title=Bvlgari Hotels & Resorts Official website|last=|first=|date=|website=bulgarihotels|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} ==Boutiques== Bvlgari relies on a distribution network of about 300 stores. The largest Bvlgari store in the world is the 10-story Bvlgari Ginza Tower in [[Tokyo]], 940 square meters of retail floor space, including a restaurant and lounge bar.{{citation needed|date=November 2016}} North American Bvlgari boutiques and distributors are found in Aspen, Atlanta, Beverly Hills, Bal Harbour, Boca Raton, Bethesda (Chevy Chase), Charlotte, Chicago, Costa Mesa, Dallas, Honolulu, Houston, King of Prussia, New York, Las Vegas, Los Angeles, Mexico City, Cabo San Lucas. [[Image:Man with a Movie Camera by Dziga Vertov.jpg|thumb|Dziga Vertov, ''Man with a Movie Camera,'' Opening shot, 1929]] '''''Cinéma Pur''''' ([[French language|French]] for "Pure Cinema") was an [[avant-garde]] film movement begun by filmmakers, like [[René Clair]], who "wanted to return the medium to its elemental origins" of "vision and movement."<ref name="books.google.com">Frank Eugene Beaver. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=Jj7vAjkArz4C&pg=PA267 Dictionary of Film Terms: The Aesthetic Companion To Film Art]''. Peter Lang; 2006 [cited 13 September 2012]. {{ISBN|978-0-8204-7298-0}}. p. 23.</ref>
==History== [[File:Man Ray 1934.jpg|thumb|U.S. photographer and filmmaker [[Man Ray]] (pictured here in 1934) was part of the [[Dada]]ist "cinema pur" film movement, which influenced the development of art film.]] The term was first coined by Henri Chomette. <ref>[http://www.academia.edu/1572733/Discovering_Pure_Cinema_Avant-Garde_Film_in_the_1920s Discovering Pure Cinema: Avant-Garde Film in the 1920s]</ref> The goal of the movement was to create a cinema that focused on the pure elements of film like motion, visual composition, and rhythm. It was begun by European filmmakers [[René Clair]], [[Fernand Léger]], [[Hans Richter (artist)|Hans Richter]], [[Viking Eggeling]], [[Walter Ruttmann]] and others. They sought to accomplish their goal by minimizing story and plot, focusing instead on visual concerns by using close-ups, dolly shots, montage, lens distortions, and other cinematic techniques. Films like ''[[Ballet Mécanique]]'', ''[[Symphonie diagonale|Symphony Diagonale]]'', and ''[[Berlin: Symphony of a Metropolis|Berlin: Symphony of a Great City]]'' projected rhythm and motion in the title of the films and the works themselves. In addition to close-ups, other filmmaking techniques were used to create rhythm and visual interest. They include [[Time-lapse photography|fast]] and [[slow motion]], [[Special effect|trick shots]], stop-action cinematography and dynamic cutting.<ref>Frank Eugene Beaver. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=Jj7vAjkArz4C&pg=PA267 Dictionary of Film Terms: The Aesthetic Companion To Film Art]''. Peter Lang; 2006 [cited 13 September 2012]. {{ISBN|978-0-8204-7298-0}}. pp. 23-24, 39.</ref>
The clearest examples of pure cinema are said by essayist and filmmaker Hubert Revol to be documentaries.<ref name="Aitken2002 page 72">Ian Aitken. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=95hztKqwDxEC&pg=PA80 European Film Theory and Cinema: A Critical Introduction]''. Indiana University Press; 1 January 2002 [cited 14 September 2012]. {{ISBN|978-0-253-34043-6}}. p. 72.</ref>
{{Quotation|Documentary must be made by poets. Few of those within French cinema have understood that in our country, we possess innumerable elements and subjects to make, not just insignificant ribbons (of film), but splendid films lively and expressive... The purest demonstration of pure cinema, that is to say of poetry which is truly cinematographic, has been provided us by some remarkable films, vulgarly called documentaries, particularly ''[[Nanook of the North|Nanook]]'' and ''[[Moana (1926 film)|Moana]]''.<ref name="Aitken2002 page 72"/>|Herbert Revol, filmmaker and essayist}}
==Story/Narrative Reduction== The Dadaists saw in cinema an opportunity to transcend "story", to ridicule "character," "setting," and "plot" as bourgeois conventions, to slaughter causality by using the innate dynamism of the motion picture film medium to overturn conventional Aristotelian notions of time and space. The movement also encompasses the work of the feminist critic/cinematic filmmaker [[Germaine Dulac]], particularly ''[[Thème et variations]]'', ''Disque 957'', and ''Cinegraphic Study of an Arabesque''. In these as well as in her theoretical writing, Dulac's goal was "pure" cinema, free from any influence from literature, the stage, or even the other visual arts.<ref name=Beaver>Frank Eugene Beaver. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=Jj7vAjkArz4C&pg=PA267 Dictionary of Film Terms: The Aesthetic Companion To Film Art]''. Peter Lang; 2006 [cited 13 September 2012]. {{ISBN|978-0-8204-7298-0}}. p. 23-24, 39-40, 90.</ref><ref>Tami Michelle Williams. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=zAvxStNOkLMC&pg=PA10 Beyond Impressions: The Life and Films of Germaine Dulac from Aesthetics to Politics]''. ProQuest; 2007 [cited 13 September 2012]. {{ISBN|978-0-549-44079-6}}. p. 7.</ref>
==Art form== It declares cinema to be its own independent [[art]] form that should not borrow from literature or stage. As such, "pure cinema" is made up of nonstory, noncharacter films that convey abstract emotional experiences through unique cinematic devices such as montage (the [[Kuleshov Effect]]), camera movement and camera angles, sound-visual relationships, super-impositions and other optical effects, and visual composition.<ref name=Beaver/>
==Other terminology== Critics and artists used terms such as [[Absolute Film]], '''True Cinema''', and "Integral Cinema" <ref>[http://www.centerforvisualmusic.org/library/WMAbsoluteFilm.htm]</ref>— Dulac's term which might better be translated "Self-Sufficient" or "Complete" Cinema — to stress that these works, all of them, functioned only as cinema art: that they could not exist in any other medium because their essential effect arose from the unique potentials of the cinematic mechanism, such as flexible montage of time and space, measured pacing and control of gaze, exact repetition, single-frame diversity and continuity, superimposition and its related split-screen imagery. <ref>[http://www.academia.edu/1572733/Discovering_Pure_Cinema_Avant-Garde_Film_in_the_1920s Discovering Pure Cinema: Avant-Garde Film in the 1920s]</ref>
==Influential examples== [[Cinéma Pur]], a 1920s and 1930s French [[avant-garde]] film movement also influenced the development of the idea of "art film." The cinema pur film movement included [[Dada]] artists, such as [[Man Ray]] (''[[Emak-Bakia]]'', ''[[Return to Reason]]''), [[René Clair]] (''[[Entr'acte (film)|Entr'acte]]''), and [[Marcel Duchamp]] (''[[Anemic Cinema]]''). The Dadaists used film to transcend narrative (storytelling) conventions, bourgeois traditions, and conventional Aristotelian notions of time and space by creating a flexible montage of time and space.
Chomette adjusts the film speed and shoots from different angles to capture abstract patterns in his 1925 film ''Jeux des reflets de la vitesse'' (''The Play of Reflections and Speed''). His film made the following year, ''Cinq minutes du cinéma pur'' (''Five minutes of Pure Cinema'') reflected a more minimal, formal style.<ref name="Aitken2002 page 80">Ian Aitken. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=95hztKqwDxEC&pg=PA80 European Film Theory and Cinema: A Critical Introduction]''. Indiana University Press; 1 January 2002 [cited 14 September 2012]. {{ISBN|978-0-253-34043-6}}. p. 80.</ref> Germaine Dulac's goal of "pure cinema" and some of her works inspired the French [[Cinema pur]] film movement. ''{{lang|fr|Theme et variations}}'' (''Theme and Variations'') and ''Disque'', both made in 1928, are two examples of cinéma pur by Dulac.<ref name="Aitken2002 page 80"/>
Man Ray directed a number of influential [[avant-garde]] short films, known as ''[[Cinéma Pur]]''. He directed ''[[Le Retour à la Raison]]'' (2 mins, 1923); ''[[Emak-Bakia]]'' (16 mins, 1926); ''[[L'Étoile de Mer]]'' (15 mins, 1928); and ''[[Les Mystères du Château de Dé]]'' (27 mins, 1929). <ref>[https://hirshhorn.si.edu/explore/film-pure-man-ray/ Film: Pure Man Ray]</ref> Man Ray also assisted Marcel Duchamp with the cinematography of his film ''[[Anemic Cinema]]'' (1926) <ref>[https://mubi.com/films/anemic-cinema Anemic Cinema (1926)-MUBI]</ref>, and Ray personally manned the camera on [[Fernand Léger]]'s ''[[Ballet Mécanique]]'' (1924). <ref>[https://mubi.com/films/ballet-mecanique Ballet mécanique (1924)-MUBI]</ref>
Director [[George Lucas]], as a teenager in [[San Francisco]] during the early 1960s, saw many exhilarating and inspiring abstract 16mm movies and nonstory noncharacter 16mm visual tone poems screened at cinematic artist [[Bruce Baillie]]'s independent, underground [[Canyon Cinema]] shows; along with some of [[Baillie]]'s own early visual motion pictures, Lucas became inspired by the work of [[Jordan Belson]], [[Bruce Conner]], [[Will Hindle]], and others. Lucas then went on to enroll as a film student at [[USC School of Cinematic Arts]], where he saw many more inspiring cinematic works in class, particularly the visual movies coming out of the [[National Film Board of Canada]] like [[Arthur Lipsett]]'s ''[[21-87]]'', the French-Canadian [[cameraman]] [[Jean-Claude Labrecque]]'s [[cinéma vérité]] ''60 Cycles'', the work of [[Norman McLaren]], and the visualist [[cinéma vérité]] documentaries of [[Claude Jutra]]. Lipsett's ''21-87'', a 1963 Canadian short [[abstract film|abstract]] [[collage film]] of discarded footage and city street scenes, had a profound influence on Lucas and sound designer/editor [[Walter Murch]].<ref>{{Cite book|last=Pollock|first=Dale|authorlink=|authors=|others=|title=Skywalking: The Life and Films of George Lucas|year=1983|publisher=Elm Tree Books|location=London|isbn=0-241-11034-3}}</ref> Lucas greatly admired [[pure cinema]] and at film school became prolific at making 16 mm nonstory noncharacter visual tone poems and cinéma vérité, with such titles as ''[[Look at Life (film)|Look at Life]]'', ''[[Herbie (film)|Herbie]]'', ''[[1:42.08]]'', ''[[The Emperor (film)|The Emperor]]'', ''[[Anyone Lived in a Pretty How Town (film)|Anyone Lived in a Pretty (how) Town]]'', ''[[Filmmaker (film)|Filmmaker]]'', and ''[[6-18-67]]''. Lucas's aesthetic and style was also strongly influenced for the ''[[Star Wars]]'' films. Lucas tributes to ''21-87'' appear in several places in ''Star Wars'', with the phrase, "[[the Force]]", said to have been inspired by ''21-87''. Lucas was passionate and interested in camerawork and editing, defining himself as a filmmaker as opposed to being a director, and he loved making abstract visual movies that create emotions purely through cinema.<ref>Steve Silberman. [https://www.wired.com/wired/archive/13.05/lucas.html?pg=3&topic=lucas&topic_set=%20Life%20After%20Darth ''Life After Darth.''] George Lucas interview. Wired. May 2005. Retrieved September 13, 2012.</ref><ref>Dan Brown. [http://www.cbc.ca/arts/features/starwars/ ''Star Wars: the Canadian angle.''] CBC News Online. September 8, 2004. Retrieved September 13, 2012.</ref>

It was established in 1987 by [[Thomas O'Regan]] and Brian Shoesmith. It is edited by Panizza Allmark (Senior/Chief Editor), John Tebbutt and Timothy Laurie. The journal is published by Taylor & Francis.
For over thirty years it has contributed to the formation of the discipline of media and cultural studies by identifying new areas for investigation and developing new agendas for enquiry in the fields. The journal has consistently provided a space for important new voices in media and cultural studies, while also featuring the work of internationally renowned scholars. '''''Continuum''' ''is now one of the most highly regarded and most cited journals in media and cultural studies.
The journal is of central importance to all scholars involved in the research and teaching of media and cultural studies. It provides vital information and ideas for thinking about the formations of media in culture and wider issues of culture.
== Abstracting and indexing == The journal is abstracted and indexed in the [[International Bibliography of the Social Sciences]].
